title: ‘Young Woman Reading’ Nets £6.3M, an Auction Record for Osman Hamdi Bey
text:
Text size

Young Woman Reading by 19th-century Turkish painter Osman Hamdi Bey realized £6.3 million (US$7.8 million), including premium, at a Bonhams auction in London on Thursday, setting a new world record price for the artist at auction.

The sale price was also more than 10 times its presale low estimate of £600,000.

The previous record for Osman Hamdi Bey (1882-1910) was his 1906 painting The Tortoise Trainer, which fetched 5 million Turkish Lira (about US$3.5 million) in December 2004 at the Artam Antik A.Ç. auction in Istanbul.

“Young Woman Reading was one of the finest of Osman Hamdi Bey ’s paintings to appear at auction in recent years,” Charles O’Brien, Bonhams head of 19th-century art, said in a statement. “I am not surprised that the bidding was so strong and that it set a new world record sum for the artist.”

The 1880 painting Young Woman Reading depicts a kneeling young girl reading the Qur'an against a colorful background with Islamic designs, and “demonstrates the unique nature of Osman Hamdi’s Orientalism, and his artful game,” Bonhams said.

Orientalism, or Orientalist art, is a style that often features rich-colored and detailed depiction of life in the Ottoman Empire, North Africa, and the Middle East. Orientalists were largely 19th century European artists, and Hamdi Bey was the only Middle Eastern painter to have worked in this same Western style.

The Connoisseur by Ludwig Deutsch Courtesy of Bonhams

He began to study painting under the great French Orientalists Jean-Léon Gérôme and Gustave Boulanger, while completing his law studies in Paris in 1860. His paintings were exhibited at the 1867 Paris Exposition Universelle and he continued to paint throughout his life.

Another masterpiece by Hamdi Bey, Koranic Instruction, 1890, will be featured at Sotheby’s sale of Orientalist paintings from the Najd Collection in London on Oct. 22. It has a presale estimate of between £3 million and £5 million.

Young Woman Reading was the star lot of Bonhams sale of 19th-century European, Victorian, and British impressionist art, which achieved a total of £11 million.

Three other orientalist works by the Austrian Orientalist painter Ludwig Deutsch all sold far above their estimates. The Qanun Player sold for £1.2 million against a low estimate of £300,000; The Connoisseur sold for £337,563 against a low estimate of £150,000; and The Goza Smoker sold for £1.1 million, which was more than eight times its presale estimate.
